Now spight of Subtle Foes all Danger's past,
And Heav'n on Vertue showrs Rewards at last.

div.stage: The End of the last ACT.

div.head: The Four Seasons or Love in every Age. A Musical Interlude. Set to Music by Mr. Jeremy Clarke.
div.stage: This Entertainment is perform'd at the End of the last Act, but was design'd for another Season, and another Occasion: And what is mark'd thus (") is omitted.
div.p: THe Overture is a Symphony, lofty, yet gay: At the latter part, it changes to a flat adagio; to which mournful Movement

l.hi: The Genius of the Stage appears in a melancholic Posture, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Genius.
sp.l: " Mourn, drooping Seat of Pleasures, mourn.
" Mourn what all others bless, the Summer's warm Return.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: " Mourn, drooping Seat of Pleasures, mourn!
" Thy darling Guests, thy fair, thy best Supports,
" For rival Fields forsake our lovely Sports:
" We grieve alone, while Birds and Shepherds Sing.
" Alas, we bear a Winter in the Spring.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: " Mourn, drooping Seat of Pleasures, Mourn!

sp.speaker: Mr. Freeman.
sp.l: While a gay March is perform'd Apollo appears.

sp.speaker: Apollo.

lg.l: Rouse, rouse, ye tuneful Sons of Art!
The Soul of Numbers and of Days,
Infusing Life in ev'ry Part,
Appears, your fainting hopes to raise.
" Advance in Crouds, soft Pleasures, sprightly Joys,
" Tune ev'ry Lyre, raise ev'ry voice.
" Advance, soft Pleasures, sprightly Joys.
" While your * * Mr. Henry Purcel. Amphion plai'd, and Sung,
" Your Thebes in decent Order sprung.
" Let harmony be thus employ'd,
" To raise what Discord has destroy'd;
" And Musick, that ev'n Trees can move,
" Shall draw the Fair from ev'ry Grove.
Revive, ev'ry Pleasure, and die, ev'ry Care!
Ye Ages of Life, and ye Seasons appear!
Show now, that, as Love in all Ages can warm,
So Harmony here in all Seasons can charm.

sp.l: Revive, ev'ry Pleasure, and die ev'ry Care! &c.

stage.hi: While the Chorus repeat that verse, the Scene changes, and discovers the four Seasons, on four several Stages. The Genius and some of his Attendants withdraw.

sp.speaker: Miss Campion.
sp.stage: Enter a Girl of Thirteen or Fourteen years old.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Must I a Girl for ever be!
Will n'er my Mother marry me!
They tell me I'm Pretty,
They tell me I'm Witty:
But when I would Marry,
She cry's, I must tarry,
Must I a Girl for ever be!
Will ne're my Mother marry me!

sp.speaker: Youth.
sp.l: Oh! Miss! The Spring is come again,
The pretty Birds sing, bill, and cooe:
All dance in Couples on the Green:
'Tis time we shou'd be doing too.
My Dear, let's marry; then will you and I,
As Man and Wife togetherly.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Peace, naughty Thing! I heard one say
That Marriage is no Children's Play.
Think you to have me for a Song?
Besides, they tell me I'm too young:

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: No, now to wed betimes is common:
When e're you marry, you're a Woman.
Come, I must have you, quickly too,

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Fy, why d'you make so much ado?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fy, I'm asham'd! Fy, what d'you do?

div.stage: Both repeat their last Line together.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Be quiet, or I'll call my Mother.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Nay, prethee, let me take another.

div.stage: Both repeat their last Line together.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Another Kiss, and then—

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Another, and another.
Come, never fear, you'll quickly know,
Tho I am little, soon I'll grow.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Oh, no, no, no. Oh, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Oh let us go. You'll find it so.

div.stage: They repeat their last Line together for a Chorus.

div.head: The Dance of Spring here.
div.stage: Enter two young Lasses with Baskets of Flowers, and Nosegays in their hands. They Dance.
Enter to them two young Sparks, the Lasses, dancing, offer 'em Nosegays, curtisying, and smiling. The Sparks make love to 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lindsey.
sp.stage: Enter a Country Lass with a Rake, as at Hay-making.

lg.l: " Oh Why thus alone must I pass the long day!
" Were a Gentleman by, 'twere sweet to make hay,
" And on the Grass coupled to jig it away.
" I'll then go sell all, ev'n my Rake and my Pail,
" To buy a high Topping, and hugeous long Tail.
" Your Powder'd wild Bores will then all come to woo,
" i'll learn how to flaunt it, and quickly come to,
" And serve a Town Husband, as other Wives do.
" I hate a dull Clown who knows hardly what's what,
" Who shrugging and grinning stands twirling his Hat,
" Nor dares tell a Body what he wou'd be at.
" With smoke and worse-Liquor he sots and he Feasts,
" And instead of his Mistress he fondles his Beasts.
" With his hands in his Pockets he whistling goes by,
" Or by me on a Hay-cock he snoring does lie,
" When the Booby much better himself might employ.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis sultry Weather, Pretty Maid,
Come, let's retire to yonder shade.
sp.stage: She stands bashfully hiding her face.
sp.l: Pray, why so shy? Why thus d'ye stand?
Sure 'Tis no Crime to touch your hand.
Oh let me take a civil kiss!
sp.stage: She Curtsies when he kisses her.
sp.l: What harm is there in doing this?
Fy, why d'ye cover thus your Brest?
One Favour more, and then I'm blest.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: Oh pray, Sir.
Nay, nay, Sir.
Oh fie, Sir.
Oh why, Sir.
Why do you
Now pull me thus to you?
Oh what shall I say!
When a Gentleman suiters 'tis hard to say nay—
I'm e'en out of Breath; Oh, dear! what d'ye do?
Good La! Is it thus that you Gentlefolks woo!
Good, Sir, do not hold me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good Lass, do not fly.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: What good can I do you?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come yonder, we'll try.

sp.speaker: Lass.
sp.l: No, no; I can't find in my heart to comply.

div.stage: Enter an African Lady, with Slaves who dance with Timbrels. A Negro Lord makes Love to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Pate.
sp.stage: Enter a Lusty Strapping Middle-ag'd Widow all in Mourning. She weeps and blubbers.
sp.l: Oh my poor Husband! For ever he's gone!
Alas! I'm undone.
I sigh, and I moan.
Must I these cold Nights lie alone!
Alas! I'm undone—
I did what I list:
We kist, and we kist:
But his Health soon he mist,
And thro Business and Care he ceas'd to be gay;
And at last, poor Soul! he dwindled away,
We wrangled
And jangled
When in an ill mood,
Yet often like Pigeons we bill'd and we coo'd.
'Tis done.
Oh! he's gone
Alack, and alack
I must now for ever do Penance in Black.

sp.speaker: Mr. Leveridge.
sp.stage: Enter a Drunken Officer, Reeling, he hickhups.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Why, Widow, why Widow! What makes thee so sad?
Art thou mad?
If one Husband is gone, there are more to be had.
Come, I'll be thy Hony!— Leave keeping a Pother,
One Man like one Nail serves to drive out another.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: How! Talk so to me! What, think you I'd Wed?
'Tis scarce a Month yet since my poor Hony's dead.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: A Month! 'Tis an Age. You're mad to delay.
Most Widows now chuse e're the Funeral Day.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Not I: I'll ne're do't. Fy, what would People say?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: They'll say, you're a Woman. Come, away with this Fan!
See! See!— here's a Shape!— here's a Grace,— here's a Leg! here's a Man,
I'll get thee with Twins, till a hundred and ten.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You lie,— go, you'll talk at another rate then.

div.stage: She pats him in a smiling way.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Then try me.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: I'll do't by this Kiss.
By this, this, and this!
I'll be hang'd if I miss.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Oh should I do this!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Twill ease you of Pain.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Go, you're a sad Man!

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: I'll kill thee with Kindness.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Ay, do if you can.

div.stage: A French Country-woman with Grapes and other Fruits comes in, in Wooden Shoes, a French Vintage-maker makes Love to her in a Dance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Crossfield. Mrs. Lindsey. Miss Campion. The Boy.
sp.stage: While four of five Bars are perform'd by a Thorough Base, enter an Old Gentleman, in an Old-fashion'd Dress, following a Young Lass, or Girl, and pushing a Youth from her. An Old Woman, in an Old-fashion'd Dress, comes and Thrusts him away from the Young Couple, The Old Woman sings like one without Teeth.

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Hold good Mr. Fumble, Fy! What do your mean,
To court my my Grand Daughter? She's scarce yet fifteen.
And you H'usi'fe; why stay you? go get you to School.
Your Baby go dandle,
I'll handle
This doating old Tool.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Hold, hold!
Do not scold.
With my Grandson go cooe.
You love him I know.
Together go cooe!
" Good Lad, prethee do.
" Tho he's somewhat bashful, he'll quickly come to.
I'm not yet so old,
I long to be at her, to have and to hold.
I'll wed thee,
I'll bed thee,
I'll rouse thee,
I'll touze thee,
I'll give thee what's better and sweeter than Gold.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: No, no, you're too old.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Dear Girl, why so shy?

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Old Man why so bold?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Good Lad, how d'you do?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ne're the better for You

sp.speaker: Old. Wom.
sp.l: Hold! Boy! I am brisk yet.
And gayly can frisk it
I've yet three good Teeth, and a Stump.
And see I can caper and jump;

sp.speaker: Old Man
sp.l: Why thus do you shun her? What makes you so bold?

sp.speaker: Old Wom.
sp.l: Why thus do you shun him? What makes you so bold?

sp.speaker: Boy and Girl.
sp.l: Indeed you're too old.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: I find 'tis in vain!
Come, no longer let's strain.
Let the Young take the Young, Let the Old take the Old.
sp.stage: The Old Man goes and takes the Old Wom. by the hand, and she him, hugging one another.
sp.l: We'll hug our selves warm, now the Weather is cold.

div.stage: All the four repeat the last two Lines as a Chorus. Enter a Dutch-woman with a Stove warming her self, her Cloaths lin'd with Furs. An Old Miser makes Love to her in a Dance.

lg.l: Come all, come all— Enter the Ages and Seasons.
" Let soft Desires your Heart engage,
" 'Tis sweet to Love in ev'ry Age.
" Ev'ry Season, ev'ry Creature,
" Yeilds to Love, and courts his Joys.
" None are Truer, none are Sweeter
" When Discretion guides the Choice.
" Cupid with the Four Ages and the Four Seasons, mingle in a Dance while the following Grand Chorus is sung. Grand Chorus of all the Voices and Instruments.
Hail, Soul of Desire!
Hail, Guide of the Year!
All Ages you fire.
All Seasons you cheer.
Thus ever conspire,
And reign ev'ry where.
" Love blooms in our Spring. The four Parts of Music answerable to the four Ages of Life and Seasons of the Year, sing each the Line that's suitable to them.
" In our Summer it grows.
" In our Autumn 'tis ripe.
" In our Winter it glows.
Hail, God of Desire!
Hail, God of the Year!
All Ages you fire.
All Seasons you cheer.
Thus ever conspire,
And reign ev'ry where

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.l: HOld, pray don't thrust me on— hold! I'm asham'd.
Well, if I speak, the Op'ra will be damn'd.
D'you think by me to get an act of Grace,
And gain the Ladies with my Charming Face?
No, I'm too Modest, and dread coming on,
As a poor Poet dreads a hiss or dun.
I doubt, no Epilogue will please the Town,
Loose Jests and Smut are damnably cry'd down.
Had Joe Haines sung one, h'has a way so winning,
'T might pass perhaps, like fine Italian Singing.
Then my best way is humbly thus to fall.
Good People, pray, our Op'ra do not mawl!
With rueful Phiz I beg it of you all.
Dear Friends above, for me do your Endeavour,
Stand by me still: Now, now's the time, or never.
Sure I at least the gentle Masks shall please,
They can't deny a Man upon his Knees.
To please the Beaux, I'll study new Grimaces,
For they're bely'd, or they love ugly Faces.
Their own, I mean, in their dear Looking-Glasses.
To please you, Criticks, who fit here uneasy,
I'll study— Nothing— for nothing e're cou'd please ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ro.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, methinks you better words might use.
We should beg Favour, and Defects excuse.
Pray let me try that less presuming Way,
And humbly beg Indulgence, for the Play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Penk.
sp.l: With all my heart, and so I'll sneak away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rog.
sp.l: In altering Plays, there's an ungrateful Curse:
Some still will say they're alter'd for the worse.
If ours be so, sure 'tis a Plot on us;
For he that did it writes for t'other house:
Perhaps he does so now two several ways;
Those write for Them who bring us wretched Plays.
If with his Stuff he meant our house to break,
To disappoint him, kind Sirs, let it take.
Let this Play live; then we stand bravely fixt,
But let none come his third day, nor the sixth.
To you, bright Beauties, all our Joys we owe,
You're the kind Stars from whom our Blessings flow.
Cheer'd by your Beams we boast a second Life,
And Pleasure's doubled by a gen'rous Strife.
To prop us now, new Favours on us show'r,
And still be great in Mercy, as in Pow'r▪
